body: • A review of a concert by Rufus Wainwright at the church of St John at Hackney, London, said that he had dedicated “a musical reading of Thomas More’s The Last Rose of Summer to Prince”. It was the 19th-century Irish poet Thomas Moore who wrote The Last Rose of Summer, not the 16th-century statesman and Catholic martyr Sir Thomas More (‘He liked guns and other men’: exuberant Rufus revamps Shakespeare’s sonnets, 28 April, page 34). • The author of a Notebook column (29 April, page 33) wrote that she had been “feeling a little guilty about Melania Trump lately, after referring to her derisively as a ‘Slovakian model’”. Trump, a former model, is not Slovakian. She was born in 1970 in Slovenia (then part of Yugoslavia) and became a US citizen in 2006. • Several readers noticed a mismatch between the clue for 3 down in last Friday’s quick crossword, “General Motors’ German subsidiary (4)”, and the solution required to fit the grid, Opal. The car manufacturer described in the clue, based in Rüsselsheim, Hesse, is Opel, not Opal (No 14,344, 29 April, page 32, G2).
